The sequence of meanings in the text of this sÅ«tra cannot be understood by the world's ignorant wisdom,
I bow to this teacher of ours, whose body is born of boundless merit,
One should pay homage to him who possesses such virtues, and hold his footprints on one's head,
He who can ride the difficult-to-harness chariot of enlightenment, with the intention to universally benefit all sentient beings.
The sÅ«tra says able to bestow the most supreme benefit - this refers to mature bodhisattvas.
Able to entrust the most supreme - this refers to immature bodhisattvas.
How is it the most supreme benefit for bodhisattvas?
Furthermore, what is the most supreme entrustment?
To answer these questions, the verse says:
The most supreme benefit should be known to be for the body and its dependents,
Attaining and not regressing on what has not yet been attained, this is called the most excellent entrustment.
This means that for the sake of the bodhisattva's body, one is able to benefit them and also benefit their associated retinue, which is called the most excellent benefit.

In their bodies, one causes the Buddha's teachings to mature and be gathered, thus benefiting their bodies, and also causes the abilities of transforming other sentient beings to be accomplished, thus benefiting their retinue.
In this way, one should know that for the merits that have been attained and those that have not yet been attained, one is able to act as the cause for their non-retrogression.
Entrusting to the excellent friends is called entrusting through excellent entrustment.
Here, attaining and not regressing means causing them not to abandon the Great Vehicle;
Not regressing on what has not yet been attained means causing them to progress to the most excellent in the Great Vehicle.
For those who have set out on the bodhisattva vehicle, how should they abide?
To answer this question, the verse says:
In the mind, vast and supreme, reaching the ultimate without error,
The abode of the beneficial intention, the merit of this vehicle is complete.
What does this clarify?

If bodhisattvas give rise to these four kinds of beneficial intentions, they then begin to give rise to the mind of abiding in the Great Vehicle and being endowed with this intention, and can be called one whose merit is perfect.
What are the four kinds of beneficial intentions?
First, vast;
second, supreme;
third, ultimate;
fourth, without error.
The sÅ«tra says, Those who set out on the bodhisattva vehicle should give rise to this mind, and so forth up to 'all of this,'  which clarifies the beneficial intention of vast benefit.
I will cause them all to enter nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder and attain liberation clarifies the beneficial intention of supreme benefit.
Although one liberates immeasurable sentient beings, up to not being called a bodhisattva, clarifies the beneficial intention of ultimate benefit.
What is the meaning of this?
It clarifies that all sentient beings are all included in the same as the bodhisattva's own body. Because of this, it is only quiescent extinction, and there are no separate sentient beings.
If one makes separate sentient beings and does not think of them as one's own, then one is not called a bodhisattva.
If one includes them in one's own essence, then it is ultimate non-abandonment. Therefore, it is called the ultimate intention.

If a bodhisattva has the thought of self, the thought of sentient beings, the thought of a living being, and the thought of a person, then he is not called a bodhisattva, this clarifies the intention of non-inverted benefit.

This is because the thought of self and so forth arises based on the view of a real self. In order to correctly eliminate this, it is non-inverted. The following will show that those who set out on the bodhisattva vehicle should practice in this way.
The sÅ«tra says, The bodhisattva should not abide in phenomena when practicing giving. It explains this extensively.
What is the meaning of this here?
Does the single term giving encompass all six perfections?
The answer is:
The six perfections are all called giving, due to wealth, fearlessness, and the Dharma.
Here, the first, second, and third are called the practice of non-abiding.

In order to clarify that these six all have the characteristics of giving, this giving nature is due to wealth, fearlessness, and the Dharma. Wealth giving is due to one, which is the first giving of fearlessness;
due to two, which is morality and patience. In the case of no enmity, it is morality; and in the case of an enemy, it is patience. Because one is not afraid;

Dharma giving is due to three, which is diligence and so forth. Due to the absence of weariness, one is diligent; having understood the minds of others, one is concentrated; and one proclaims the true Dharma with wisdom.
This is the place of practice for great bodhisattvas, and it is precisely by means of the single term giving that the six perfections are completely encompassed.
The sutra says, Bodhisattvas should practice giving without abiding in things. What is meant by the nature of non-abiding here?
A verse says:
In order to repay one's own body, the fruits and retributions are all unattached.
As for the phrase not dwelling on things, this shows non-attachment to one's own body and not dwelling on the circumstances.
As for the phrase one should practice giving, this shows non-attachment to repaying kindness and to gain and respect, etc.
The circumstances of seeking kindness and expecting benefits are many, therefore it is said that one should not give rise to attachment to the circumstances and practice giving.
As for the phrase not dwelling on form, etc., this refers to non-attachment to the fruits and retributions.
Question:
Why is it necessary to practice giving in this way without dwelling?
The verse says:
In order to avoid not giving rise to it, and to avoid giving for other practices.
Because of caring for one's own body, one does not practice giving. In order to avoid the mind not giving rise to it, one should not be attached to one's own body and quickly practice giving.

Because of the mind expecting kindness and hoping for results, one abandons the nature of the fruit of right enlightenment and bodhi, and practices giving for other things. Therefore, one should abandon seeking to give for other practices.
The following will explain the method of subduing the mind.
What is the matter?
Subduing is in the three wheels, eliminating the mind of characteristics,
Later, all doubts and confusions that arise are all eliminated.

The sÅ«tra says, Bodhisattvas should practice giving like this, and should not even be attached to the thought of characteristics. This shows that one should eliminate the thought of attachment to the three things: the objects to be given away, the sentient beings to whom one gives, and the one who gives.
Next, it clarifies the benefits of giving.
There may be a question:
Since one is free from characteristics in giving and so forth, how can one obtain the benefits of merit?
In order to answer this, it says that the merit produced is very much.
Question:
Why is the benefit of practice not stated after the practice, but only mentioned now in the section on subduing?
Answer:
It is to show that if a person is not attached to characteristics, they can then practice giving without attachment.
From here on, all the subsequent sutra text is to dispel doubts one after another.
Here, there arises such a doubt.
Question:
If one does not become attached to the Dharma when practicing giving, how does one practice giving in order to seek the supreme fruit of perfect enlightenment?
In order to answer this doubt, the sutra says, What do you think?
Can one see the Tathagata through his excellent characteristics? and so on, explaining in detail.
The verse says:
If one takes the creation of the excellent characteristics as the collection, they are not the excellent characteristics,
Because they are subject to the three characteristics of change. There is no such thing as the Tathagata.

If one says that the Tathagata is created by the causes and conditions of giving and so forth, and attains the nature of supremacy among conditioned things, then one sees the Tathagata as having excellent characteristics.

If one regards the true nature of the Tathagata, then there are no such excellent characteristics. Therefore, one should not see the Tathagata through excellent and wonderful characteristics, because that Dharma body is not manifested by what is created through accumulation.
Next, it says, Why is it so?

The TathÄgata says that those superior characteristics are subject to the three characteristics of change. Therefore, those superior characteristics are not superior characteristics. The meaning here is that the essence of the three characteristics is subject to change and flow.
SubhÅ«ti!

All superior characteristics are false. Therefore, one should view the TathÄgata with superior characteristics that are not characteristics. This meaning intends to clarify that dharmas produced from causes are false and nonexistent.
This means that because the TathÄgata is completely devoid of the three kinds of characteristics, by being apart from these characteristics, he is characterized by being without characteristics.
If in this place there is no nature of birth, abiding, cessation, or change that can be known, this shows that the TathÄgata is not a nature that is produced by conditioned arising.

Thus, having clearly understood the nature of the TathÄgata, although one practices giving for the sake of the fruition of Buddhahood, one is not attached to giving the Dharma, which is precisely removing doubts.
Next, SubhÅ«ti gives rise to doubts again:
If one practices giving without attachment in this way, then the cause is extremely profound;
Furthermore, it is said that the TathÄgata is of the nature of the unconditioned, which is precisely the fruit being extremely profound.
How can there be those who have faith in the latter age, causing their karmic retribution not to be wasted?
In order to sever this doubt, a verse says:
The cause and effect are profound, spoken in that evil age,
This is not without benefit, due to the three kinds of bodhisattvas.
Even if there are bodhisattvas with precepts, virtues, and wisdom in the latter age, because of this teaching the fruit and benefits are not wasted.
A verse says:
Because in the past, under the buddhas, they upheld the precepts and studies,
And planted good roots, they are called those with precepts and virtues.

The sutra says, However, that bodhisattva does not serve a single Buddha, nor does he plant various roots of goodness in a single Buddha. This shows that for the sake of upholding the precepts in the presence of past Buddhas, one practices respectful service and plants various roots of goodness. The order is precisely the possession of precepts and the possession of virtue.
Next, clarifying the person who possesses wisdom. The verse says:
Because one is able to sever the thought of self and the thought of dharmas,
This is called possessing wisdom. The two sets of four are distinguished to form eight.
This clarifies that there are four thoughts of self and four thoughts of dharmas, thus forming eight thoughts.
The verse says:
Having a separate substance, continuing to arise, abiding until the end of life,
Again seeking other destinies, there are four kinds of thoughts of self.
The four thoughts of self refer to the thought of self, the thought of sentient beings, the thought of the life-force, and the thought of seeking another destiny. The four are not the same.

In regard to the individual aggregates, sentient beings naturally give rise to the notion of self, and seeing the continuity arise, they form the notion of sentient beings. Sattva means continuity, up to the duration of life. When the life faculty ceases, seeking another existence, they form the notion of further seeking rebirth.
As for the four notions of dharmas, the verse says:
Because they are all nonexistent, they are not existent; because they exist, they cannot be said to be nonexistent.
Because they are the cause of verbal expression, the notion of dharmas has four aspects.
As for the four aspects of the notion of dharmas:
First, the notion of dharmas;
Second, the notion of the nonexistence of dharmas;
Third, the notion of existence;
Fourth, the notion of nonexistence.
This means that because the grasped and the grasper are all nonexistent, the notion of dharmas does not arise, which is precisely the notion of the nonexistence of dharmas.
The nonexistence of those dharmas has the nature of emptiness, so it is not the notion of the nonexistence of dharmas.

That nonexistence has the nature of neither existence nor nonexistence, so it is not a notion because it cannot be expressed in words. Because it is the cause of verbal expression, it is not the notion of nonexistence.
Because of the power of thought, although not manifested by words, it exists due to verbal expression, with eight meanings that are not the same.
Because of the cessation of the eight thoughts of self and dharmas, it is called having wisdom.
Why is this meaning only spoken of those who have wisdom, and not of those who have precepts or virtue?
Answer:
In order to show that there are differences in true thoughts.
What are they?
The verse says:
Because of the power of faith and understanding, one gives rise to true thoughts due to faith,
Because one does not grasp according to the words, and because one grasps as the correct teaching.

For this reason, it is said that only such a person can hear this sutra and give rise to one thought of faith. Because one who has wisdom does not grasp according to the words, and because one accords with the wisdom of the supreme truth, one grasps it as the correct teaching, and therefore it is called true thought.

For this reason, after speaking of them, it is said, One should not grasp them as dharmas, nor should one grasp them as non-dharmas. One should not take what is said as the Dharma, nor should one immediately grasp them as non-dharmas. Because this is the wisdom that accords with the ultimate truth, and grasping them is the correct teaching.
This is the sutra's statement, Hearing this sutra, one gives rise to true faith.
The sutra says, SubhÅ«ti!
The TathÄgata has already known and seen these people. What meaning is revealed by this?
The verse says:
The Buddha understands the results without inference, because he knows through the knowledge of vows.
The results possessed by those who are fully endowed with precepts, the Buddha does not understand through inference, but rather through direct perception by the knowledge of vows.
If he did not say seen, one might think he understood through inference;
if he did not say known, one might fear it was the seeing of the physical eye, etc. Therefore, both knowing and seeing are mentioned.
Why did the World-Honored One speak in this way?
The verse says:
It is to prevent them from speaking of themselves for the sake of profit and respect.
Those who are endowed with precepts and so forth, seeking profit, offerings, and respect, speak of their own virtues, and then give rise to the thought:
Since the TathÄgata has already perceived me from afar, it is not appropriate for me to speak of myself.
The sÅ«tra says: SubhÅ«ti!
Those sentient beings will give rise to immeasurable accumulations of merit and gather them. What does this refer to?
It means causing their accumulations of merit to be born, and moreover, that merit will be able to continue and infuse without interruption.
As for saying there is the grasping of self and so forth, it means there is the nature of latent tendencies, not that there is the grasping of present activity.
The sÅ«tra says: Therefore, the TathÄgata secretly expounds the Dharma door of the analogy of a raft.
Those with wisdom should still abandon the Dharma, let alone the non-Dharma.
What is the secret meaning here?
The verse says:
Realizing non-abiding in the Dharma, it is for the sake of following.
It is like abandoning the raft, this is the hidden meaning that should be known.

It means that the Dharma of the sÅ«tras and so forth is not the supreme abode of realization, and once realization is attained, one should abandon those teachings, like abandoning a raft once one has reached the other shore;
Because the supreme realization is in accordance with it, one should accept it, like necessarily relying on a raft before reaching the shore.
This is called the hidden meaning.
On a single raft, there is both accepting and abandoning, therefore it is called hidden.
If it is any other Dharma that is not in accordance with realization, it should be abandoned.
Next, it further removes doubts.
What is it?

The above text says, One should not view the TathÄgata with superior characteristics, because he arises from the nature revealed by the unconditioned. If this is so, then how can it be said that ÅšÄkyamuni TathÄgata realized supreme perfect enlightenment and was able to proclaim the Dharma teachings?
Due to this principle, he is not the correct enlightenment, nor does he expound the Dharma.
To answer this doubt, the verse says:
The transformed body is not the true Buddha, nor is it the one who expounds the Dharma.
Because there are three kinds of Buddhas:
First, the Dharma body Buddha;
Second, the enjoyment body Buddha;
Third, the transformation body Buddha.
As for the Buddha Shakyamuni, he is the transformation body. He is originally neither the one who attains enlightenment, nor the one who expounds the Dharma to deliver beings.
The text says, Why is it so?

The Dharma expounded by the Buddha... and so forth, in order to refute the idea that all expounding of the Dharma is false, it says, The transformed body is not the true Buddha, nor is it the one who expounds the Dharma.
However, it is not completely non-existent. The verse says:
The expounding of the Dharma is neither of the two graspings, and what is expounded is apart from verbal expression.
These two kinds, namely the nature of dharmas and the non-nature of dharmas, cannot be heard by the ears nor spoken by the mouth.
Therefore, one should know that it is neither dharmas nor non-dharmas. This is said based on the principle of suchness.
That is not the Dharma, because it is said to be the nature of the unconditioned.
It is also not non-Dharma, because that which has no intrinsic nature does exist.
Why is it only said to be the spoken Dharma, and not the realized person?
The answer:
By only saying what is spoken, the meaning of realization is made clear, because there is nothing spoken that is not realized.

The sÅ«tra says because all sages are manifested by the unconditioned to clarify the cause of speaking this Dharma. Because all sages are manifested by the pure Dharma of suchness, it is called manifested by the unconditioned. Therefore, they still speak of the unconditioned Dharma.
As for the statement all things that cannot be expressed by words, how could they be grasped?
Because their intrinsic nature is not the domain of verbal expression, it is clarified that this is the nature of non-verbal expression.
Why is there no distinction made here, and sages are spoken of in general, not only Buddhas?
The answer:
It is to clarify that all sages manifest from the purity of suchness.
Because there is complete purity and partial purity, according to what is appropriate, there is no fault.
Also, it is said that the differences in blessings are to be revealed. What is the meaning of this?
The answer:
Although the Dharma is truly of the nature of the ungraspable and the unspeakable, it is still beneficial.
The verse says:
Receiving it oneself and explaining it to others, not without benefit, accumulating blessings.
Why does the sutra say, World-Honored One!
This accumulation of blessings is not an accumulation. Therefore, the Tathagata speaks of it as an accumulation of blessings, an accumulation of blessings?
The verse says:
Blessings do not uphold enlightenment, because those two are able to uphold it.
It is said that blessings cannot uphold and bear enlightenment, because the two are able to uphold enlightenment. The meaning of the verse is like this.
What are the two?ğŸ”½They refer to receiving it oneself and explaining it to others.
The sutra says, Having received it oneself, one explains it to others.
If one does not understand this statement, what meaning is it referring to?
The Sanskrit word for aggregate is saá¹ƒghÄta, which has many meanings, either the meaning of aggregate, or the meaning of shoulder, or the meaning of section.
If it is translated according to this region as aggregate, it only gets the meaning of accumulation and loses the other meanings.
Here it is based on the two kinds, which were not understood by the ancients, and it is translated as course, which is deeply off the mark.
Moreover, it should be known that this meaning of aggregate and the meaning of shoulder are extremely difficult to understand when explained. There are two kinds of meanings:
The first is the meaning of accumulation;
The second is the meaning of bearing.
Just as on the shoulder one can carry a load, it is called a shoulder and an aggregate.
For this reason, the accumulation of that merit is called a heap of merit.
Because it is unable to bear enlightenment, it is called not an aggregate, which is the meaning of accumulation, not the meaning of shoulder.
These two are causes of enlightenment, and the merit is very much.
Question:
Why are these two able to uphold enlightenment?
In order to illustrate this meaning, the sutra says, Why is it so?
SubhÅ«ti!
Because the unsurpassed enlightenment of all TathÄgatas comes from this sÅ«tra.
Why is enlightenment called coming out and the Buddhas called born?
The verse says:
Because it obtains the intrinsic nature and cause, the other is born.
What is called enlightenment is precisely the Dharma body. Because this is unconditioned, it is called the intrinsic nature.
Therefore, these two are the causes for obtaining it, not the causes for its arising.
If it is compared to this, the other enjoyment and transformation bodies are the causes for its arising.
Because of this, it is able to directly uphold enlightenment, and the merit produced is very great.
In order to illustrate this meaning, the sutra says, Why is it so? and so forth.
Why is this the establishing cause?
The verse says:
Because it is only the Buddha Dharma, it is able to accomplish the supreme merit.

As for the statement the TathÄgata says it is not the Dharma of the Buddha, this shows that the Dharma that is realized can only be personally experienced by the Buddha. Because of its unique nature, it is therefore supreme. Because this is the nature of the supreme cause of merit, it attracts the most merit. The meaning clarifies that this is the direct cause that can accomplish supreme merit.

The above sÅ«tra says, The sages are all not revealed by the compounded, and For these sages, the realized Dharma cannot be grasped and cannot be spoken. All the sages such as the stream-enterers all grasp their own fruits. How can this be established as the nature of the ungraspable?
That which is proclaimed regarding what is grasped is not of the nature of the unspeakable.
In order to dispel doubts, the following text is produced, which clearly shows the well-established principle of the ungraspable and unrevealed truth.
The verse says:
Because it does not grasp its own fruit, it is not graspable or speakable.

Because it is revealed by the unconditioned nature, there is not the slightest dharma to be attained among the six sense objects. Since there is nothing to be attained, it is called the stream-enterer.
Even up to arhats, there is no dharma, the principle is all the same as this.
The essence of unconditioned dharmas is ungraspable, therefore the sages do not grasp or speak of their own fruits.
If the sages were to think like this:
I have attained the fruits, then they would have the grasping of self and so forth.
The meaning is that there are latent afflictions, not manifest ones, because when they realize and contemplate, they do not have the grasping of self and so forth, yet say I have attained.
Why did SubhÅ«ti himself say he has attained arhatship?
In order to let some beings know he has personally realized it.

Moreover, he himself said he has attained the state of no dispute, in order to show that his body is endowed with supreme virtues, and in order to cause others to give rise to supreme respect and faith.
With what intention did he say that SubhÅ«ti has no abode at all, yet he says he has attained the state of no dispute, and attains the state of no dispute?
The verse says:
Because he is liberated from the two obstructions, SubhÅ«ti is said to have no dispute.
There are two kinds of obstructions:
The first is the afflictive hindrances;
The second is the hindrances to samÄdhi.
Because one is liberated from these, one does not abide in the two hindrances. This is why it is mentioned twice.
This statement of the two kinds of non-disputation is precisely the non-existence of disputation.
Next, doubt arises and it is said:
The World-Honored One, in the past, with DÄ«paá¹ƒkara Buddha, did there exist any dharmas that could be grasped? He also spoke to others the essential teachings.
Based on this, how can one attain non-grasping and non-speaking?
In order to answer this difficulty, it is said: In truth, there are no dharmas that the TathÄgata grasps.
What is the meaning of this?
The verse says:
In the presence of DÄ«paá¹ƒkara Buddha, it is said that the Dharma of realization is not grasped.
This means that the World-Honored One, in the presence of DÄ«paá¹ƒkara Buddha, also did not use words to grasp the Dharma of realization.
The verse says:
Because of this, the Dharma of realization is accomplished as that which is not grasped or spoken.

If it is said that all sages are manifested by the unconditioned, and that dharma is neither that which is grasped nor that which is spoken, how do bodhisattvas grasp the excellent adornment of the buddha lands?
Moreover, how does the enjoyment body itself take on the role of Dharma King, and how does the world regard it as the Dharma King?
In order to dispel doubts, the following text is produced.
The meaning here is as follows. A verse says:
The flow of wisdom is the nature of consciousness only, and the lands are not what is grasped.

Because in reality there is no excellent adornment of the buddha lands that can be grasped. Except for what flows from the pure wisdom of the buddhas and is manifested by consciousness only, this cannot be grasped.

If it is said that there is a real form that can be grasped, and that one will accomplish the excellent adornment of the lands, this is a false statement. The Buddha says that it is not excellent adornment, and for this reason it is said to be the excellent adornment of the lands.
What is the meaning of this?
A verse says:
Because it is formless and supreme, it is not adornment but the nature of adornment.
As for adornment, there are two meanings:
One is form and appearance;
The other is the superior appearance.
This supreme one is the ultimate truth, because it is formless.
The adornment of the Buddha land is not adornment, because it is not true adornment. Therefore, this is called supreme, because the supreme Dharma is gathered here.
If one grasps the superior form and adornment of the Buddha land, thinking I will accomplish that, then one's mind will be attached to form and other sense objects.
In order to prevent this view, the text states not abiding.
As for the question of how the enjoyment body Buddha can be the Dharma King for himself and others, in order to answer this difficulty, the enjoyment body is likened to Mount Sumeru.
What meaning does this text wish to illustrate?
The verse says:
It is like the wondrous high mountain, which in its enjoyment has no grasping.

Just as the king of the wondrous high mountain, having attained the nature of supreme great lordship, is called wondrous high, yet does not itself grasp the nature of being the king of mountains, because the mountain has no discriminating nature.

The enjoyment body Buddha is also like this. It is endowed with the nature of the Dharma king, because by attaining the nature of supreme great lordship it is called supreme great, yet it does not itself grasp the nature of the Dharma king, thinking I am the Dharma king, because it is without discrimination.
How can it attain this nondiscrimination?
In order to reveal this meaning, the text says, The TathÄgata says it is not a body, because that which does not exist is said to be a body.
What is the meaning of this?
The verse says:
Because it is not of the nature of the contaminated, nor is it created by causes.
However, because the enjoyment body is not of the nature of the contaminated, therefore it is said to be existent although it does not exist, because its pure essence is clear and distinct.
It is also not created by causes, because this body does not arise in dependence on other causes and conditions.
Why did he previously explain the simile of merit and now explain it again?
The verse says:
In order to show many distinctions and achieve excellence,
The merit before and after is not the same, so he presents the simile again.
Previously it was explained that the merit of the three thousand worlds is vast,
Now it is said that countless three thousand worlds are even more extensive.
Why was this simile not mentioned before?
It is because those who receive the teaching have different preferences, some preferring little and others preferring much. The intention is here.
The previous distinction of merit did not clarify the cause of establishment, and it has no function of supporting enlightenment;
Now, in order to manifest the characteristics of the cause of establishment, another simile is used to speak according to the matter.
